dt: {bc}to remove utterly from recognition or memory

dt.t: … a successful love crowned all other successes and {it}obliterated{/it} all other failures.

dt: {bc}to remove from existence {bc}destroy utterly all trace, indication, or significance of

dt.t: The tide eventually {it}obliterated{/it} all evidence of our sandcastles.

dt: {bc}to cause (something, such as a bodily part, a scar, or a duct conveying body fluid) to disappear or collapse {bc}{sx|remove||4}
{bc}to make undecipherable or {d_link|imperceptible|imperceptible} by obscuring or wearing away

dt.t: A dimness like a fog envelops consciousness / As mist {wi}obliterates{/wi} a crag.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}oblīterātus, oblitterātus,{/it} past participle of {it}oblīterāre, oblitterāre{/it} "to cause to be forgotten or fall into disuse, make disappear," from {it}ob-{/it} "against, facing" + {it}-līterāre, litterāre,{/it} verbal derivative of {it}lītera, littera{/it} {et_link|letter:1|letter:1} {ma}{mat|ob-|}{/ma}

The original meaning of {it}oblīterāre{/it} was apparently "to wipe out letters, words, etc.," but this sense is not clearly attested in classical Latin. Attested senses appear to have been influenced by {it}oblītus,{/it} past participle of {it}oblīvīscī{/it} "to forget, put out of mind" (cf. {et_link|oblivion|oblivion}).
shortdef: to remove utterly from recognition or memory
to remove from existence : destroy utterly all trace, indication, or significance of
to cause (something, such as a bodily part, a scar, or a duct conveying body fluid) to disappear or collapse : remove
